security_audit.summary: This is a legitimate browser automation tool using Playwright. It executes external browser processes and writes to local filesystem for state management. While it has elevated capabilities, they align with its stated purpose of browser debugging.

medium_findings.title: External browser process execution
medium_findings.description: The skill launches Chromium browser as a subprocess with remote debugging enabled. While legitimate for browser automation, this could be misused if the browser is launched with malicious arguments.

low_findings.title: Writes state to user cache directory
low_findings.description: The skill writes browser state and logs to ~/.cache/pwdebug/. This is normal behavior for a debugging tool but represents filesystem access beyond its own directory.

content.user_title: Debug Web Apps with Browser Automation
content.value_statement: Frontend debugging is time-consuming when you need to repeatedly launch browsers and navigate to test pages. This tool provides a persistent browser session with CLI commands for navigation, JavaScript execution, screenshots, and element inspection.
actual_capabilities: Launch persistent Chromium browser with CDP debugging
Execute JavaScript expressions in browser context
Take screenshots of full pages or viewport
Interactive element picking with CSS selector generation
limitations: Chromium browser only (no Firefox or WebKit support)
Requires local browser installation via Playwright
No built-in authentication or session persistence

use_cases.title: Debug Web Applications
use_cases.description: Quickly test JavaScript code, inspect elements, and capture screenshots during development without repetitive browser launches.

use_cases.title: Automated Testing Setup
use_cases.description: Create reproducible browser sessions for testing web applications with precise control over navigation and interactions.

use_cases.title: Dynamic Content Inspection
use_cases.description: Analyze dynamically generated content and test CSS selectors before implementing scraping scripts.

prompt_templates.title: Basic Navigation
prompt_templates.scenario: Open a website and take a screenshot
prompt_templates.prompt: Start the pwdebug browser service, navigate to https://example.com, and capture a full-page screenshot

prompt_templates.title: JavaScript Testing
prompt_templates.prompt: Execute this JavaScript on the current page: document.querySelectorAll('a').length

prompt_templates.title: Element Selection
prompt_templates.prompt: Use the element picker to locate and provide CSS selectors for all navigation menu items

prompt_templates.title: Console Monitoring
prompt_templates.prompt: Start watching console logs, refresh the page, and show me any errors that appear

output_examples.input: Pick the login button on this page

best_practices: Always stop the browser service when finished to free system resources
Use headless mode for automated tasks running in CI/CD pipelines
Clear browser profile periodically to avoid cached data interference
anti_patterns: Never execute untrusted JavaScript code in the browser context
Avoid running multiple browser services simultaneously on the same port
Do not use element picker on sensitive pages with personal data

faq.question: Which browsers are supported?
faq.answer: Currently only Chromium browser is supported through Chrome DevTools Protocol (CDP).

faq.question: Where are screenshots saved?
faq.answer: Screenshots are saved to your system's temporary directory with timestamp-based filenames.

faq.question: Can I use this with existing Playwright scripts?
faq.answer: Yes, the tool uses standard Playwright CDP connections and can complement your existing automation scripts.

faq.question: Is the browser data persistent between sessions?
faq.answer: Browser profile data is stored in ~/.cache/pwdebug/profile and persists until manually cleared.

faq.question: How do I stop the browser service?
faq.answer: Use 'scripts/pwdebug.py stop' command or press Ctrl+C in the terminal where it was started.

faq.question: Can I run multiple browser instances?
faq.answer: Only one instance can run on the default port. Use --port option to run multiple instances on different ports.
